label: Letter 2 from Sidney Jennings Legendre, July 25, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing his adventures boarding a battleship and recounting the events of the days spent on the ship. He continues in his letter to assure her that he made every attempt to have her join him in Hawaii and assure her of his love.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
26
July 25, 1943
Dear Gertie,
I received your letters of July 17th. , one
dated Monday from the colony club and one dated July 20th.
The latter was very depressed and I gather that you again
think I do not love you and that the world is going to hell.
The latter is very likely true, but the former is j st as
foolish as ever. I did write you between July third
and eleventh and tomorrow when I go to the office I will
look up the days I wrote you on as I keep a list there.
However you will find that I have not written you between
the twentieth and the twenty fifth because I went to sea
on a battleship. Gill Aertson, the boy that we went to
see at a cocktail party at the house near Katherines
is an aide to an admiral. He asked Morris if one of us 
would like to go on this cruise which would include some
minor manouevers. Morris was so busy that he told me to
take the opportunity so offI went. It was quite remniscent
of the days on the Guinevere when we use to said the oceans
with the Palmers. I reported on board at seven in the
morning. Morris dxrove me to the dock and he and I spent
ten minutes arguing which gang plank I shou[l]d go up, as one
is reserved for officers and the other for men. The one
for officers has the officer of the deck at the head and
you salute him, present your orders, and say"report on board
for duty sir." Well of course I listened to Moonface and
as a result went up the gang plank for enlisted men. There
naturally was no one ot take my orders and the enlisted men
were in a turmoil as to what to do with me. Trundling my
suitcase I preceded forward and from the stern of a
battleship tot he front is a long way. When I had arrived
I confronted the offcer of the deck from behind and he
was so suprised that he allmost fainted as he had been
watch[i]ng the gang plank and of course could not understand
that an officer in the navy would use the wrong gang plank.
I asked for Aertson and was sent away with a guide. We went
through rabbit warren after rabbit warren until finally
in a hole below the surface of the water I found him asleep
stretching out on his bunk stark naked and dripping perspiration
at the rate of a gallon a minute in the terrific heat.
Battleships do no have any port holes so there is only the
original air that was enclosed at the time of building and
a strange smelling substance that everyone assured me was
pumped in from the outside[,]but that smelled like old rubber
to my not too delicate nostrils. I awoke my host and
after dressing we both went to the ward room for breakfast
By this time I to was wringing wet and mopping my brow with
a saturated handerchief. From breakfast we went up on what
[End Page 1]
is known as the fl g deck. It is called this I am certain
because I do not think anything else could survive there
very long as there is absolutely noth ng to sit down on.
I walked the deck like Nelson from seven thirty to elecen
thirty[,]between moments [scratched through] I was pressing myself against
the railings to let Captains and Admirals pass. Then my
feet hurt so much that I climbed into a little chair that
was jutting out form the railing l ke a window bo[x]. I had
a premonition that it was something special as no one used
it all morning and certainly there must have been other
acking feet besides my own. Down I sand in this haven of
comfort, lifted my aching puppies up from the deck and sighted.
I did not have time to finish the sigh before I was plucked 
out of my seet and
warned never to do that again as that was the admirals seat.
Back I went to pacing with many a thought of the soft chairs
on the mainland. At twelve e went below for luxnchoen and
had a soup watered with perspirations and other goodies. I was
sleepy and asked where I was supposed to sleep and received
the startling answer that there was not any bed for me they
were all occupied but that we would see what would turn
up during the course of the day. Back I went to pacing the
deck my feet crying out pitifuly at each step, until suddenly,
I was almost blwon off them completely by a broadside of cannon.
After that I did not bother who I talked to as I could not hear
what they said anyway. When the guns were not going off loud
spearkers were urging men and officers to go here and there.
The man giving the orders had never learned to speak English
but I was told that after several months on board you pick up
his language and can understand him, although no one has ever
learned to speak as well and with the same inflection as he.
He sounds like a train announcer t the grand central with a
bad cold. We went through terrfice manouvers gainst an
imaginary enemy . It was like rushing around on one side of
a tennis net making terrific shots, serving, ground strokes
etc. wi hout any opponent. or balls. At six we went down for
dinner and then back to pacing until eleven when I was informed
I was to sleep on the Captain sofa in his cabin. I immediately
went there, stri[p]ped off my clothes and lay down on the leather
sofa. Sweated like a pig, have you ever laid on bare leather
without any clothes on. It sticks to you like a saddle to the
strappings of your bre[T]tches. I had hardly fallen asleep before
the loud speekers heard of ti and went off with a bang. They
are always g[iv]ing some order and when there is nothing else to do
they shout "pipe the sweepers". This means that all the unlisted
men g[r]ab their brooms and start sweeping. The next morning I 
was awakned at qu rter to five and the day was repeated except
that I tried to go down and sit on the main deck under one of
the big guns and get a little rest. I had hardly been there
ten seconds before those ghastly louxd speakers found me and
roared"clear the decks. " I tumbled down a hatch , and grouped
my way to my frinxds cabin hoping to lie on his bed and sleep.
Howe er he had been on watch all night before so he was already
in bed and had ac uired a nice coat of perspiration by time I
arrived. Back I went to the deck and paced back and forth.
[End Page 2]
Aside from this side of it the cruise was intensely interesting
I learned a great deal about the conditions the men live under
the typed of information they wanted form our office and what
they thought of things we had already published. The officers
and men were exce[e]dxingly nice and some of them the most attra-
ctive I have ever met. The ship was run beautifuly and was
clean as a pin and the manouvers gave you a great deal of
confidence in our Navy and the men who run it.
You know how you have thought that I never have
tried to get you out here or made an effort to have leave.
I wrote you that there is not to be anymore leave until the
war is over. Today we received an order that men who ask 
for a transfer of service to some other station of branch of
the service will be regarded as attmepting a subterfuge to
return to the mainland and will be treated accordingly. If
I only could impress upon you to things,
1. I love you just ast much
2. I tried all channels to get you out here and
there was'nt a pray.
I think you would be much happier. In your new position sweet
heart stop worrying about whether I love you and try to
have a good time. You will receive this letter at your
new address and I send with it all my love and best wishes.
Your cable saying you were telephoning tomorrow night
was waiting for me on my return. I look forward so
much to talking to you dea[r].
Sidney J Legendre
P.S Today is sunday, I worked at the
office so have no news of the beach
At the office morning: I wrote you on July 1,3,5,9,10,11,12,14,17,19,20
and today the 25th.
[End Page 3]
